title: What make acoustic guitar did Paul McCartney use to record the song Yesterday? - Quora

response.answer_text: Like Rolf Fahlén already stated, Paul recorded “Yesterday” on his Epiphone (by Gibson) 1964, FT-79 Texan. He bought it at the end of August 1964 at Manny’s in New York City. It had a Natural coloured solid spruce top, a mahogany back and sides, with serial number 194959. It was sold in the US at the time for about 1000 pounds in today’s money. It’s a right-handed model that Paul turned upside down and he had it strung left-handed. He also used it for live performances of “Yesterday” during The Beatles years and beyond, although during the Wings’years he also used a Gibson or Ovation while performing the song. In 1976, while performing in Detroit with Wings, Paul stuck a Red Wings sticker of the Detroit NHL hockey team, given by a fan, on this guitar, and it has been there ever since. When Pail played in Pittsburgh in August 2010, Pittsburgh’s fans, seeing hem play with a sticker of their rival hockey team, asked the Pittsburgh Mayor to convince Paul to add a Pittsburgh Penguins sticker to the guitar, which Paul did. He hasn’t played it live anymore for a couple of years now, since “Yesterday” hasn’t been on his set list lately.

A very grainy picture, but here is Macca playing the guitar Monique referenced, with both teams’ stickers on it.  Epiphone did a limited edition re-release at some point. One sold at auction for £2,200. Lot 159 - Epiphone limited edition Paul McCartney 1964 Epiphone Texan acoustic guitar, made in USA Some, at least, were “played and signed” by Paul, and sell for rather more. 2005 Limited Edition Epiphone Texan Paul McCartney, Aged #33 of 40 | Used Acoustic Guitars | Wildwood Guitars On one, at least, he also doodled some artwork on the guitar, for a 2007 Starbucks competition. A Jolt for McCartney Fans Part of his arrangement with Gibson/Epiphone is that some part of the proceeds goes to a land mines charity, a cause his late wife Linda was passionate about.
I think it was an Epiphone (by Gibson) 1964, FT-79 Texan.
